transcript.text:
Dear followers of dewereldmorgen.be (that's 'the 
world tomorrow' in English). Tonight we have the

honor of speaking to two of the most prominent voices 
of the left in the world, Noam Chomsky and Vijay

Prashad. Welcome, the occasion is the publication of 
the Dutch translation of their book 'The withdrawal'

in an excellent translation by Tineke Jager, barely 
one week after the English original. Very good.

Professor Noam Chomsky needs no introduction 
to our followers We publish translations of his

articles and interviews on a regular basis. They 
they are very well read. At 93 years of age, he is

still at it about the world as ever. His historical 
knowledge and analysis remain an essential tool

of information. I personally discovered him 
in 1979 with the double book

'The Political Economy of Human Rights' with Edward 
Herman, went back from there to his previous

books and never stopped reading. Way back then,
when I started reading, I was convinced I was the

only one in the country who read such books like 
this. I could not be more wrong.

To read Chomsky is to gain an understanding of the 
world as it really is, as today with this new book.

Vijay Prasad, I had the privilege of meeting you 
here in Ostend about a year ago. Remember how we

stood in front of the big statue of our 
mutual friend King Leopold II one year ago.

You keep amazing our readers and me with your 
keen knowledge and understanding of the world. You

travel around the world, talk to the people that 
matter. I saw your picture with Lula in Brazil.

For our readers and followers, he really 
is the new guy to follow. He's also prolific writer,

author of many books and articles, one of them by 
the way is 'Washington Bullets', translated in Dutch

with a title that even English speakers 
can understand 'Imperialisme voor beginners'.

Google him for many more. Vijay, professor, you're 
welcome. I just read the translation of 'The Withdrawal'.

Great foreword by Angela Davis by the way. 
Last year the two of you had talks about a

range of subjects. It's a look back and look 
forward, starting from that 'withdrawal' from

Afghanistan. Vijay, you also mentioned several other 
books from the past, like 'American Power and the

New Mandarins' and 'The Backroom Boys', books 
that are really essential reading, even today.

Vijay, professor, in your talks you went back in time
to that other 'withdrawal' in 1975, the one from

Vietnam. Also you talk - very importantly - 
about the forgotten country in that war: Laos

Could I have from the both of you 
your view on both 'withdrawals'? How

similar or different are they? Why does 
it matter today to know this history? Please.

Well, this was a large part of my life. 
I should say from about 1960 until

the present. In fact I was able to 
visit Laos, spend some time there in 1970.

I also visited North Vietnam at the same time, 
but was deeply involved in both? Why should

we be concerned about them? I think they're the 
most important events since the Second World War.

There's been nothing comparable to 
the US Devastation of Indochina (Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia),

which includes Cambodia, which I didn't get 
to. The bombing of Cambodia in the early 1970s

is one of the gravest modern crimes.
It was carried out on the orders

of one of the biggest western criminals, 
the highly respected Henry Kissinger,

who transmitted to the Air Force the orders of his 
half-drunk president (Richard Nixon). The order words were

massive bombing of Cambodia: 
"Anything that flies against anything that moves".

I doubt that one can find in the archival record a 
comparable call for mass genocide, you might look.

"Anything that flies against anything that moves". 
Well, it was done. One of the consequences it led

to was the enormous birth of the Khmer Rouge from 
a small guerrilla movement to this mass

of infuriated peasants seeking revenge. The 
consequences we know. In the case of Laos,

it was basically,  probably the most
heavily bombed area in history. Northern

Laos was a sideshow, had almost nothing to do 
with the Indochina War. There was a trail, the

Ho Chi Minh trail, which led the support for the 
South Vietnamese and their resistance against the

U.S invasion, which was their main goal. Northern Laos, 
where the bombing was, had nothing to do with it.

In fact US high officials conceded 
in Congress that much of the bombing

of Northern Laos was undertaken when there 
were bombing halts over North Vietnam.

They had nothing to do with the planes. 
So, let's bomb northern Laos,

probably about the most primitive societies you can 
imagine, scattered villages. Most of them

didn't even know they were in Laos. I was able 
to interview lots of refugees, who fled when

a CIA trained mercenary army went through the region, 
to drive them out, down right to the president. Their

children are dying from unexploded bomblets, little 
tiny small bombs that are scattered around.

A kid will just pick it up, because it looks 
interesting and explodes in his face. The US

is doing almost nothing to help with the removal 
of theses bombs. Some volunteers are doing something.

I mean, the main target of the 
attack was South Vietnam, always,

a devastating attack on South Vietnam. Why should 
we understand about it? Well, because it is the

worst major crime since the Second World War with 
enormous consequences. What about the withdrawal?

Why did the U.S withdraw? Well, there was a 
major huge offensive, an uprising. It's called

the Tet Offensive. It was actually a popular uprising 
in January 1968, one of the most amazing events

in modern history. The country South Vietnam was 
completely saturated with U.S troops and troops

of the Saigon Army, that the U.S had established. 
over a million of them. Every village had informers,

troops and so on. The uprising was unknown to the 
occupiers. It was organized without any

spilling out of information that it was 
going to happen all over the country.

This made it very clear - I mean the U.S was able 
to finally put it down with tons of bombing

and massacres and so on. But it made it very 
clear to the leadership in the United States

that they can't win this war at an acceptable 
cost. So it set in motion the beginnings of

a drawn out withdrawal, with innumerable 
monstrous crimes, but it finally ended.

according to the standard version, 
almost universal, the U.S lost this war.

That's a very revealing concept. The fact 
is the U.S attained all of its war aims.

The only thing it failed to do was turn Vietnam 
into something like the Philippines, a colony.

Didn't manage that. The Vietnamese were able 
to resist sufficiently to survive but in other

respects, if you look at the internal record, the 
U.S attained its goals. Back to the early sixties

and fifties, when the U.S intervened support the 
French colonialism and then took over themselves.

The goals were very straightforward. The goals were 
to prevent a successful independent Vietnam, which

would be a model that might be followed by others 
in the region to borrow Henry Kissinger's terminology.

Vietnam might be a virus that would spread as an infection.
That was his term for the (Chilean president) Allende

regime. He was instrumental in overthrowing it.
Well, what did that mean in Indochina?

It meant that the model might spread to others,  
to Thailand, Birma, maybe even to Indonesia which

was a real prize, with enormous resources, a powerful 
country. If the virus spread there,

Japan might accommodate to it as the industrial 
commercial center of Southeast Asia as

it's basically its resource base. The U.S had 
fought the Second World War to prevent that.

It was the goal of the Pacific War to prevent 
Japan from establishing a new order in Asia.

In the early 1950s the United States 
was not prepared to lose the Pacific War.

So, let's go in and smash it up. It's what do you do when 
you have a virus that's spreading infection.

Destroy the virus and inoculate the victims. 
How? By imposing brutal vicious dictatorships,

country after country. That will suppress any 
effort to follow the same path. That was achieved.

Every country of the region had a brutal 
dictatorship installed backed by the U.S.

The virus was not totally destroyed but it 
was not going to be a model for anyone.

The final success was in 1965 in Indonesia, 
when a murderous military coup took place,

supported by the United States, 
millions of people, horrible atrocities.

That was a great achievement. So there was a 
withdrawal. The U.S didn't achieve its final goals

but it achieved its major goals. A powerful violent 
state rarely fails against a third world enemy.

Vijay, when reading about 
this history, what can we learn about

what's happening today, about the withdrawal of 
Afghanistan? How similar or how different is it

from that other withdrawal from Vietnam, 
when you look back at it and forward?

You know, typically, it's always dangerous to 
make an argument by analogy. Looking

at something from the past and 
seeing if there are kind of relations

and so on. We live in a very different 
world today. Frankly in 1975

after the coup in Chile, after the destruction 
of the possibility of the establishment of

sovereignty on the African continent, after the 
terrible coup Noam just talked about in Indonesia,

it felt for the U.S war planners that the 
establishment of an alternative foundation in

the third world was not going to happen. 
They were pretty confident. They were so confident

that they had destroyed the new international 
economic order. I mean, there was no real major

success in the third world at that time. 
We are in a very different time now. In our

time the United States is in a much more fragile 
position economically. The political order within

the United States is very fractious. It had been 
so earlier, but now it's at levels perhaps not seen

before. I think - to add insult to injury - 
at the same time there are these immense

contradictions faced by the United States. China 
has made an entry onto the world stage. It's

made an entry onto the world stage, not by sending 
its military overseas - we shouldn't actually

understand it like that, because it's not accurate - 
but by investing its vast capital reserves

and by being able to sell the highest kind of 
technology, the most sophisticated technology

at relatively reasonable prices. If you 
travel to most parts of South America, Africa

or Southern Asia, it's impossible to buy the 
technological products which have the brands

of U.S corporations you know like Apple i-phones.
Much easier to buy Chinese phones. I

mean Chinese phones are the easiest things to buy, 
because they are really reasonable. In the middle

range are the South Korean phones. Samsung is 
somewhere in the middle between the Apple i-phone

and Huawei. China has made an appearance 
on the world even in a place like

Afghanistan, however desperate the situation today 
is - and let me tell you, it is very desperate now,

90 percent of the population in poverty and so on 
nonetheless um the people of Afghanistan need not

subordinate themselves entirely to the United 
States and that actually is interesting, because

it is already trading with Iran. It's already 
trading with China. I think if this conflict

in Ukraine dies down, Russian influence will be 
quite strong in Afghanistan. Well, what are

these countries, if you include Iran, they 
are the members of the Shanghai Cooperation

Organization (SCO), founded in 2001. It provides 
an alternative for countries like Afghanistan.

It might eventually provide an alternative 
for Iraq. I mean Iraq right now is in political

turbulence. The point is that the conditions are 
different. The world is not the same as it was in

1975. China is a major player on the world stage with 
the addition of other large countries like Brazil

and so on. It will provide an alternative. This 
is a threat to the United States, so that these

withdrawals are not exactly like the withdrawals 
of the 1970s. - There's so much more to be said and our

time is limited. In this video you are addressing  
a European audience. PLease elaborate

what you said in the book about the present 
subservience of Europe to the U.S as a consequence

of the war in Ukraine. When I read that, I 
said, well, this subservience goes back way before.

I give the example of my own country. In 1961 
the U.S installed nuclear warhead in Belgium,

not missiles but bombs, to be carried by Belgian 
planes launched on U.S orders. Belgium itself has no

say in them. They deny their existence even now. 
In the book also you explain that nuclear warheads

on land make no sense, that they're only useful
if you fire them immediately just before you get

incinerated. Could you elaborate a bit, the both 
of you, on this? How did this change or is

it still the same subservience 
to NATO which is the US actually?

Well, you can see the subservience very clearly 
in many dimensions. Takes sanctions now.

The United States is the only country in the 
world that can impose sanctions. It has enormous power.

U.S sanctions are third-party sanctions. 
Everyone else has to live up to them,

whether they like it or not. Here we see a 
striking difference between Europe and China.

When the U.S imposes sanctions that Europeans 
oppose, they abide by them. Europe was strongly

opposed to the US sanctions on Iran. The EU is 
strongly opposed to the US sanctions on Cuba.

They abide by them. They follow the orders 
of the Master. China disregards them.

That's what's called 'the threat of China'. It 
doesn't follow US orders the way Europe does.

As far as the missiles are concerned, 
there's many interesting aspects. It is true that

the land-based missiles are mostly a danger 
to the country itself that houses them.

It's well understood by strategic thinkers. The 
land-based misses, their position is identified.

You have land-based missiles like the Minutemen, 
missiles around the US. Russia knows

exactly where they are. That means they are 
what are called 'use them or lose them'.

If there's any threat in the world, you have to 
use those missiles or else they're destroyed.

That radically increases the threat of war. From a 
strategic point of view, they're completely useless.

Invulnerable submarines have so much firepower 
which can't possibly rely on a land-based missile.

One US Trident submarine can destroy
almost 200 cities anywhere in the world.

They're being replaced by the Virginia-class 
submarines which are much more powerful.

The land-based missiles are essentially doing 
nothing in the US. They're there for

political reasons. The Pentagon has spread them 
around in mostly rural areas, where the local

Congressman wants them, because they bring in some 
jobs. So they put pressure on Congress to keep them

there. Take the Cuban Missile Crisis, that 
almost destroyed the world. What was the

Missile Crisis about? It was about whether the U.S 
had the right to keep missiles in Turkey, aimed at

Russia, but Russia and Cuba didn't have the 
right to have missiles to defend itself from

an imminent US invasion. Now it turned out that 
the missiles in Turkey were obsolete. They were

being replaced by Polaris submarines. So the United 
States was willing to come close to blowing up the

world in order to establish its right to have 
obsolete missiles in Turkey being replaced by

more powerful ones, but Cuba had no right to 
defend itself from an imminent US invasion.

That's what goes on in the world. That's what 
power is. You see it in case after case. The Belgian

missiles you mentioned are another case. - Just 
just to clarify, in Belgium, they're not missiles

there's warheads that have to be carried 
by planes, who are even more vulnerable because

these planes have to take off and 
can be just shot down. Vijay,

you visited Europe on many cases. You came to our 
country last year. hHw do you evaluate the present.

I mean when we say 'Europe', we of course 
do not necessarily mean the population, but

the people in power. This subservience 
to NATO. How do you evaluate that?

Taht's taking us back a long way. I'm 
not going to take us back and narrate the whole

story, but look, there's something quite practical. 
Europe is linked to Asia. It is one giant land

mass, that goes back to ancient times. 
European integration, Eurasian integration

rather, has been blocked on several occasions. 
Well, colonialism was a big block

to Eurasian integration, because different European 
powers captured different parts of Asia and didn't

want to create a kind of Eurasian block. The Cold 
War was a big impediment to Eurasian integration.

When the (Berlin) Wall came down towards the end of the Cold
War, (former Soviet president) Mikhail Gorbachev, recently

deceased, talked about the common European Homeland. He could 
just as well have called it a common Eurasian

Homeland on the table. It was disregarded. The world
financial crisis (of 2008) demonstrated that Europe's

in a sense proximity to the Americas was not so 
much. Europe is much further away from the Americas

than it imagines. Europe began to naturally 
integrate with Asia on two flanks of this integration.

one was energy purchases. It's a lot cheaper to 
buy piped energy from Russia than it is to buy

liquefied energy from the Americas. That's just a 
fact, hence Nordstream I and II were created.

and before that other pipelines went through 
Poland. So Russia integrated into Europe

as a deliverer of energy. China integrated into 
Europe as a deliverer of capital and of goods as I

said earlier, often high-tech goods. That historical 
integration was taking place. Now Europe had a

decision to make in the last 10 years. Do 
we return to the Atlantic viewpoint, in other words,

allow the United States through NATO to define 
your European policy or does Europe actually

allow itself into this historical integration? In 
my opinion, the conflict in Ukraine is not so much

over Ukraine and concern for the Ukrainian 
people. That might be very loudly proclaimed but

I doubt that was the objective. The real issue was 
to either halt or at least to delay the historical

integration of Europe with Asia. We saw that before 
the Ukraine crisis with this ridiculous accusation

that Chinese telecommunications companies are 
coming, to disrupt the privacy and security

of Europeans. This statement was made after it
was revealed that the United States was

spying, not on you, they of course must be spying on
you, but they were spying on (German Chancelor) Angela

Merkel, of all people they were spying on Angela Merkel!
No revelation that (Chinese president) Hu Jintao or anybody at

the time was spying on on Chancellor Merkel. It was 
the United States. So I see this as Europe's

historical choice. Europe must choose between 
historical integration, peaceful integration

with Asia, creating a kind of Eurasian block or 
Europe is going to have to go to war to establish

itself as a beachhead of U.S power. That's the choice 
Europeans have to make. There's a good reason why

the Algerians abused (French president) Emmanuel Macron 
the other day. I think Europeans need to look in the

mirror. What does Europe want? War or peace? It's 
your choice. -  Absolutely, Vijay in your final

chapter of the book, your afterword, 
you express your admiration for

the consistency of Chomsky's analysis over 
six decades. Now this consistency is that not

also a reflection of the consistency of 
US foreign policy over all these decades?

I mean, do elections in the United States 
make any difference as far as real policy is

concerned, rhetoric, style and details 
apart. Noam, Vijay how do you assess that?

Noam, I think you should take this 
one, because this is about elections and

you've seen more elections than 
I have. Does it make a difference?

There's a statement about the foreign policies. The 
political differences stop at the border.

Foreign policy remains pretty well fixed. 
There's a reason for that. It's institutional.

It's been been observed long ago that the 
United States basically is a one-party state,

the business party which has two factions, called 
Democrats and Republicans. If you go back a

couple of decades, they weren't very different, 
somewhat, but what are called moderate Republicans

and liberal Democrats were interchangeable a lot 
of overlapping the parties. Now that's changed.

The Republican party has drifted off the spectrum. 
It's not a political party in any normal sense. In

international rankings it ranks alongside the far 
right policies in Europe with neo-fascist origins.

To be a Republican senator today you need 
two qualifications, one is to say no whenever

Mitch McConnell, Senate leader says no, to
anything the Democrats propose say no. That's

one qualification. The other qualification is to go to
(Trumps resort) Mar-A-Lago every couple of weeks to shine

Trump's shoes. That's it. Nothing else is required. 
They're terrified of Trump because he's managed

to mobilize a massive, angry, dangerous political 
resentful people, who are ready to go to war. You

want to know the future of the Republican 
Party? Take a look at the conferences that

just took place in Budapest and in Dallas. The hero
the Republican party is (Hungarian prime minister) Victor Orban

who wants to establish a Christian nationalist 
racist state which is what's called an illiberal

democracy, to keep the forms but eliminate the 
content. That's the darling of the Republican

Party. That's where they're going. So we 
still have that one business party, but one of its

factions has drifted off the spectrum. When 
you have one business party run in effect

concentrated capital, they have pretty shared 
interests. It's not entirely, there are splits but

they have generally shared interests. One interest 
is to ensure an international environment in which

US capital is free without constraints to access 
resources markets and so on. This is sometimes

made explicit by Bill Clinton, Democrat. He 
had, every president has to have a doctrine.

The Clinton Doctrine was stated explicitly, namely 
the US has the right to use force unilaterally

if necessary to maintain control over markets and 
resources. That's the liberal side of the spectrum.

Due to the race it's harsher but it's a narrow 
spectrum and within that spectrum you sometimes

have differences of tactics but not much
in the way of major policy change.

Now just as a side remark, when I was reading the 
book, you mentioned that the book by Hans von Sponeck,

(A Different Kind of War - The UN Sanctions Regime in Iraq-2006) 
did not get review anywhere. I can relate to this. He was in

Brussels a few years ago. I went to his press 
conference that he was going to give there. I

turned out to be the only journalist present, 
so it turned into an interview him.

If I may end with some observations
then I'll leave it to you if you want some

final words. Here in European mainstream 
media just regurgitate all the

things that the US government says but at the same
time it's quite common here in those very

media to speak very condescendingly about the 
average American, about his - it's mainly

about men - ignorance. Actually in my experience 
the finest alternative and

progressive media are American media, but they 
are never mentioned here in the mainstream,

let alone used as a solid information, which 
is precisely what we do. So to wrap up,

any final words that you would like to say,
Vijay on the book or anything else?

I'm really happy that EPO.be has published 
the book so quickly. I hope people read it. I hope

there will be discussions and debates. I very 
much hope that the European people come to their

senses regarding subservience to NATO principally, 
but also behind that, what NATO really is, which

is a kind of Trojan Horse for US power. 
European people are going to struggle

with extraordinarily high energy prices as a 
consequence of this blindness, this blinding way

in which they are refusing to allow negotiations 
around the war in Ukraine and this historical

process of Eurasian integration. I mean I would 
say, wake up! - Absolutely, my final word here,

there's so much more to be said about this book. 
For those of you in the audience who have

never read a book by Noam Chomsky or Vijay Prashad, 
here is your introduction. I'm just warning you, if

you read it, you're gonna want to read more.  
If you allow me just one word

in my own language to our followers. Thank you 
followers for your support and please subscribe.

Thank you very much, Vijay Prashad 
and Noam Chomsky. Bye.
